												Alexander is a mini-campaign for Rome: Total War that has you controlling Alexander the Great as he more or less destroys the Persian Empire and anyone else foolish enough to be in the vicinity circa 334 BC. It's an interesting challenge, and a nice break from the Roman focus of the game up until this point. Enterprising Alexander-likes need to be able to take on a numerically superior opponent with their own superior tactics and strategy, and a lot of what Alexander actually did is also applicable here. Hammer-and-anvil tactics, mercilessly slaughtering occupied populations, that sort of jolly thing. (It also has Brian Blessed.)Alexander's real value however lies in its serving as a base for many of the best RTW mods out there. Rome Total Realism and Europa Barbarorum are two examples of mods that frankly improve the base RTW far beyond Creative Assembly's initial efforts, as well as they did. That's why some people's Alexander playtime is much higher than it would otherwise be for the mini-campaign. Recommended for all Total Warriors.

												I finally got around to playing this 2006 expansion (11 years old) to a 2004 game (13 years ago) that at the time was a true gamechanger and a "game of the year" level historical RTS game.  The age is important to note because from my experience, the lack of recent patches has made the game buggy on, say, Windows 10.  There was a particular bug which sometimes (maybe 33%?) led to game crashes in the transition from the battlefield back to the world map.  What that meant (and because the battlefield can take a while) is that I had to do frequently crazy saves (some 2-3 minutes apart).   And that's because there's nothing quite as annoying as pulling off a brilliant battlefield win (that you easily could have lost)... and then have to do it all over again !  Okay, so how is Alexander besides the bug?  I'm a Total War fan/player, but I have to say... they sort of just didn't try that hard with this expansion, which ostensibly attempts to track the life, conquering, and world building of Alexander the Great.  There are a few things R:TW-A gets really, really, wrong.  First of all, the campaign doesn't include the Indians (and their elephants!), so the end game is really lacking.  The Persians also don't seem as intimidating as they are often portrayed in other games (and movies).  The game also *discourages* the sort of world building and infrastructure type stuff that we know Alexander and the Macedonians brought to Asia, giving all of those peoples a common thread.  Instead, one of the best strategies is to just burn cities down and move on.  That's not what Alexander the Great was about.  Having said all that, I played the expansion to the very end.  It was a long slog.  And unfortunately.... I have had better campaigns from fanmade mods.  My suggestion: C+ - a solid pass for all but the most loyal Total War fans.

												Not a bad expansion, but was unable to aquire it before getting it on Steam.Anyway...Let's get down to the important stuff. You're Macedon; you do not get to pick any other faction, and there seems to be no reward for winning that I was able to see. You don't need to worry about diplomats; they've been cut entirely out of the campaign, which means that you cannot make peace with any of the factions. To get someone to stop fighting you, you have to crush them entirely. You have 100 turns to complete the objectives you are given, with a message from the game to hurry popping up every 10 turns. Oh, and you start out with your economy going down in flames.You do get hoplite/pike armies, which are still stellar, though not quite as immune to arrows as I remember them being in vanilla Rome. It's a good thing, too, because your enemies will generally outnumber you. As a cherry on top, if Alexander dies for ANY reason, it's game over (he died once from a plague in a city that I conquered :/). You have to take your advantages and play to your strengths as a Greek/Macedonian faction to win. I eventually did, which began a short lecture on what happened after Alexander conquered Persia IRL), and then dumped me back onto the main menu (without an option to continue playing). Oh, and apparently India, while a faction in multiplayer, did not appear during my campaign, and I was unable to find a way to conquer their lone territory, which I assume has a city but I was never able to see it; due to unpassable terrain) and it was controlled by Rebels for some reason. India may have gotten eliminated due to rebellion, I don't know for sure. But it felt like a let down that I wasn't able to re-enact the Battle of the Hydapses River, which may be considered Alexander's crowning, or at least final, major achievement, in the campaign, though it is featured as a historical battle in singleplayer mode.A very demanding but managable campaign, with threats from multiple directions and having to conquer Asia while also fighting barbarians on the homefront. Ultimately, not a bad game, and I'd recommend it for players who like being challenged and don't mind a 100 turn time crunch.

Posted: April 6, 2014
												 As an avid total war fan I have nothing but praise for the original Rome and Barbarian Invasion however for me this third instalment leaves a lot to be desired. Before I criticise Alexander I do understand the premise and having played later total war games I can see that this is an early attempt at creating a "Historical Campaign" or rather a campaign with a clear story ark. I therefor view Alexander very much as Total War's fist attempt at this kind of story telling campaign, something that was only realised in Napoleon TW which was, in effect, a large linear campaign story. While Alexander's gameplay is exhalent, in line with the rest of the Rome generation, I feel that to say it is any more than an average game is, I feel, a gross exaduration. The campaign is relatively short; allows little time for you to do as you please in regards to your personal experience of the campaign and is tiresome in parts. I felt that after the initial stages of the campaign (gaining a foothold in Asia) the battles became repetitive and the A.I. predictable. I also felt that the campaign was very short and couldn't hold a candle to Rome or BI's campaigns. Custom battles are also poor with only four available factions it is easy to get bored. Macedon massively over powered, Its pikes make a mockery of most Persian units. Persia its self does have a wide array of unique and new units but they are, in my experience hard to use effectively on the battlefield. India is in my opinion a pointless addition to the game aside from elephants its armies are pitiful and it doesn't appear in the campaign. In summary I see the point of Alexander as an important experiment for total war however for me it is a solid 3 or 4 out of 10 despite some redeeming features such as narration from Brian Blessed.

												This game can be summed up succinctly by the following sentence:Meh.When you play RTW's secondary expansion - Alexander - you can help but think; 'What could have been...' 												Alexander is, without a doubt, what the later games would consider a "mini-campaign". One playable, linear (left edge of map to the right) campaign, but a few new units for others in custom battle, means that you're not going to have much variety with this mod. Why they didn't include  this  as part of the original collection and sell the much more expansion-like Barbarian Invasion for 5$, I'll never understand. But it's still only 5$ for a good six hour campaign, and a few more hours worth of historical battles. Some mods can also use Alexander for the best AI out of the Rome 1 games, as well as night battles, but mods that take advantage of that are few and far between.So, this is a hesitant recommended. If you love the basegame, go ahead, you'll enjoy this too. Or if it's on sale, grab it, up it's worth 2$ or so for sure. But for half the base game's price, it's nowhere near half the content.

Rome: Total War - Alexander is a good expansion pack for Rome: Total War. Unlike the original game itself this will take place in a far East, where you are destent to conquer the mighty Persian Empire with your superior: but outnumbered Macedonian elite forces. Using the same engine as the Rome: Total War, battles in this game run very smoothly and the gameplay is simple and fun. The expansion is about Alexanders conquest and that is what the game does: it delivers what it promises. That means only a few factions and a really straightforward campaign. (If you wanna play bigger variation of factions then theres the  Rome: Total War for that.) But unlike the original game, this expansion delivers a different, quite difficult challenge. In Rome: Total War - Alexander, you have to worry about the age of your Faction leader, deal with the lack of reinforsments and face the wrath of the Persian Empire, while trying to defend your cities from the barbarian hordes.All and all this is a expansion, that delivers different gameplay and bigger challenge, with a quality of the Rome: Total War.3/5 who said anything about the legionares? Phalangs are OP!
